annotations: Lithium–sulfur batteries (LSBs) have attracted much attention due to their high energy density, environ-mental friendliness and abundant natural reserves, and are considered a strong competitor for the nextgeneration of energy storage devices. Significant research has been conducted on LSBs over the past decade; however, the inherent lithium polysulfide (LiPS) shuttle and lithium dendrite growth problems

have been impossible to completely avoid for conventional liquid LSBs. The use of sulfide solid electro-lytes (SEs) instead of organic liquid electrolytes can completely avoid the shuttle effect and mitigate thelithium dendrite growth problem due to the rigidity of sulfide SEs, but this does not mean that sulfide-based solid-state lithium–sulfur batteries (SSLSBs) are the optimal solution. For sulfide-based all-solid-

state lithium–sulfur batteries (ASSLSBs), their inherent drawbacks, such as air sensitivity of the sulfide SEand narrow electrochemical stability window (ESW), mechanical–chemical failures caused by volumeexpansion of the active materials, and ineffective protection of the lithium metal anode, result in their commercial applications remaining challenging. A typical SSLSB usually comprises a sulfur-based composite cathode, a solid electrolyte and a lithium metal anode, where the solid electrolyte functions as a separator and conducts Li+.9 Since an inorganic solid electrolyte (ISE) is used instead of an organic liquid electrolyte, the shuttle eﬀect can be completely avoided42 and lithium dendrites are suppressed due to its rigidity. Unlike liquid LSBs, ASSLSBs with an ISE commonly have only one charge/discharge plateau and the exact reaction

pathway is still inconclusive because the solid–solid conversion reaction mechanism is more complex, but researchers have reached a consensus that the reaction mechanism of ASSLSBs follows a general electrochemical reaction: S8 + 16Li+ + 16e(cid:2) " 8Li2S. However, in polymer-based SSLSBs, two plateaus are found similar to conventional LSBs.43 This can be attributed to most polymer-based ASSLSBs operating at 60 1C, where the polymer electrolyte may dissolve, leading to the dissolution of
polysulfides and creating a second plateau.

Sulfide solid-state electrolytes

Solid-state electrolytes (SSEs) play a key role in ASSLSBs by connecting the cathode and anode, conducting lithium ions and isolating electrons in ASSLSBs. Matching an appropriate SSE is critical to achieving higher energy density, safer and more eﬃcient SSLSBs. The ideal SSE should have a high ionic conductivity (Z1 mS cm(cid:2)1) at room temperature, a low electro- nic conductivity (o10(cid:2)6 mS cm(cid:2)1), a Li+ transference number close to 1, good compatibility with metallic lithium and

sulfide- based electrodes, good thermal stability, and excellent mechan- ical and film-forming properties. In recent years, many scientists have devoted themselves to developing high-performance SSEs, and considerable achievements have been made. The represen- tative ones include sulfide SEs, oxide SEs and polymer SEs. Fig. 3 is a comparison of the performance of oxide SEs, SPEs and sulfide SEs.

Polymer solid-state electrolytes (SPEs) typically comprise polar polymers and lithium salts, which demonstrate wide ESW, good flexibility, film-forming ability, and easy processing characteristics.16 However, their room temperature ionic con- ductivity is generally insuﬃcient. For example, the ionic con- ductivity at room temperature of a PEO-based solid electrolyte is only 10(cid:2)8 S cm(cid:2)1, which is far from the requirements of the actual application. Even at elevated temperatures
(above 60 1C), the ionic conductivity of SPEs can only reach 10(cid:2)4 S cm(cid:2)1,53 temperature therefore, most SPE-based ASSLBs operate at

above 60 1C. Since PEO is in a molten state at high tempera- tures, and LiPSs can dissolve in PEO, the shuttle eﬀect will also be triggered, causing battery performance degradation.54 Additionally, due to the limited ability of SPEs to suppress lithium dendrites because of their ‘‘softness’’, all these defects limit the application of SPEs in ASSLSBs. The high- temperature sintering required for oxide SEs also increases their manufacturing cost, making them unsuitable for ASSLSB electrolytes.

Replacing the O atom in an oxide SE with the S atom, which has a larger atomic radius, lower electronegativity and weaker binding with Li+, produces a sulfide SE that demonstrates higher ionic conductivity and better compatibility with sulfur- based electrodes.30,62,63 Sulfide SEs can be divided into two categories according to their components: the first category is binary sulfide SEs, composed of Li2S and P2S5, such as Li3PS4, Li7P3S11; the second category is ternary sulfide SEs, composed of

Li2S, P2S5 and MS2 (M = Si, Ge, and Sn);64 in addition, according to the phase, they can also be divided into three categories: a glass phase, a glass-ceramic phase and a crystal- line phase. A series of sulfide SEs with ultra-high ionic con- ductivity have been developed, such as Li10GP2S12,65 Li9.54Si1.74- 67 and Li5.5PS4.5Cl1.5 (LPSCl1.5).17 Compared P1.44S11.7Cl0.3,66 Li4SnS4 with oxides and polymers, sulfides have unique merits when applied to ASSLBs. M. L. Chandrappa et al.68 have

conducted a comprehensive study on the dynamics and thermodynamics of the sulfur-based electrode/solid electrolyte interface in SSLSBs based on density functional theory (DFT) and machine learning, which shows better compatibility with the sulfur element compared with other SEs. What is more, sulfide SEs have room temperature ionic conductivity comparable to or exceeding that of liquid electrolytes, and a certain degree of flexibility, which gives them better machin- ability. Compared with

oxides, the synthesis of sulfides does not require high temperature sintering,69 thus greatly reducing their production cost. In summary, sulfide SEs have advantages over polymers and oxides, making them a strong competitor for appli- cation in ASSLSB electrolytes.

Li dendrite is one of the most notorious problems in all-solid-state lithium metal batteries (ASSLBs).74 Reducing the electronic conductivity of the SSE is an eﬀective way to promote uniform Li deposition and suppress lithium dendrite growth. Conversely, if electronic conductivity is too high, SSBs can suﬀer from severe self-discharge. Recently, M. Sun et al.75 used in situ optical microscopy to directly observe deposition of Li dendrites inside a solid

electrolyte. This straightforwardly supports the previous finding by F. Han et al.76 that lithium dendrites grow inside SEs due to the non-negligible electronic conductivity of the sulfide SEs. growth of lithium dendrites in glass-ceramic Li3PS4. 3.2.1 Stability in moist air. Exposure to humid air will cause hydrolysis of sulfide SEs, producing toxic H2S gas, which is an intrinsic defect of sulfides, especially those containing P elements. This is because the bond energy of P–S is much lower than that of P–O, making the P–S structure more prone to oxidation or desulfurization. Hydrolysis of sulfide SEs can lead to structural collapse and greatly reduce their performance, so their production must be carried out in an argon
environment.27,83,84 Many scientists are dedicated to improving air stability of sulfide SEs and a series of sulfide SEs with good air stability have been developed.

3.2.2 Compatibility with organic solvents and binders. High-energy ball milling is a common method for preparing sulfide SEs; however, this method is not suitable for industrial mass production due to its high cost, long processing time, and low yield. Therefore, SSE preparation methods must be optimized. Recently, preparation of sulfide SEs based on a liquid-phase method for high energy density ASSLBs has received widespread attention. Meanwhile, liquid-phase pre- paration can integrate the

diﬀerent components of the battery into diﬀerent configurations, which is beneficial for large-scale industrial production. However, due to its high reactivity, the choice of solvent is very limited and restricted to non-polar or weakly polar solvents. As shown in Fig. 6, highly polar solvents are usually strong Lewis bases, containing electronegative elements such as N and O with lone pairs of electrons. In sulfide-based ASSLSBs, the use of sulfide SEs can completely eliminate the shuttle of LiPSs, but this does not solve all the problems. Although there are still some challenges in material design, electrolyte preparation, interface engineering, etc., further inno- vations and breakthroughs can be expected, as more researchers devote themselves to this field. In the coming years, SSLSB technology will gradually mature and be widely used in electric vehicles, driverless vehicles, energy storage systems and other fields. Here are several principles summarized for researchers’ reference:
(1) Cathode materials and interface: a range of new sulfur- based cathodes should be developed, including transition metal sulfide, organic sulfide, monolithic sulfide doped, lithium sulfide,

lithium polysulfide, etc. What is more, in order to enhance kinetics inside the composite cathode, suﬃcient electron/ion pathways need to be constructed. Using liquid phase coated SEs to improve poor interface contact; constructing a 3D host can greatly alleviate the volume expansion of sulfur-based cathodes. Additionally, developing new binders with certain conductive properties and good flexibility is also an important strategy to solve the above problems.

(2) Sulfide solid electrolytes: for sulfide SEs, the internal dendrite growth is mainly due to their non-negligible intrinsic electronic conductivity; therefore, it is necessary to develop sulfide SEs with high ionic conductivity and electronic insulation, an attempt to coat the surface of the sulfide electrolyte particles with an electronically insulating organic layer is a feasible strategy. This approach can also improve air stability of sulfide SEs to some extent. The addition of large

amounts of conductive carbon to the composite cathode often places higher demands on the oxidation resistance of the electrolyte and doping can be considered to broaden the ESW of the sulfide SEs as well as to build a stable CEI layer. In addition, the development of fluorine containing SEs is beneficial for improving the stability of the electrolytes/lithium anode interfaces.
